facts.text: Petitioner is a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act with registered office at Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh, carrying on business in manufacture and sale of jute goods.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, its registered office being at Kanpur in the State of Uttar Pradesh, and it is carrying on business in the manufacture and sale of jute goods.

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh imposed a tax of one anna in the rupee on the sale proceeds of jute by notification dated March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated March 31, 1956, the State of Uttar Pradesh imposed a tax of one anna in the rupee on the sale proceeds of jute.

facts.text: Previously, the tax payable on sale of jute was six pies in the rupee.

anchor.surface_text: Previously thereto, the tax payable on sale of jute was six pies in the rupee.

facts.text: The notification dated March 31, 1956 was struck down by the High Court of Allahabad as unauthorised and inoperative.

anchor.surface_text: This numberification having been struck down by the High Court of Allahabad as unauthorised and inoperative,

facts.text: U.P. Sales Tax Validation Act, 1958 (U.P. Act XV of 1958) enacted validating the notification from March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: the State legislature enacted the U. P. Sales Tax  Validation  Act,. 1958  U. P. Act XV of 1958 , hereinafter referred to as the Validation Act, validating the said numberification as from March 31, 1956.

facts.text: Writ Petition filed under Article 32 of the Constitution by petitioner contending notification void notwithstanding Validation Act and Act ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: In this petition filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution, the petitioner companytends that numberwithstanding the Validation Act, the numberification in question companytinues to be void and inoperative, because it has number in fact been validated, and because the Act itself is ultra vires.

facts.text: Impugned notification superseded by fresh notification on August 1, 1956; dispute relates to tax on sales between April 1, 1956 and July 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned numberification was, it may be mentioned, superseded by a fresh numberification on August 1, 1956, and the present dispute relates only to the tax on sales effected between April 1, 1956, and July 31, 1956.

facts.text: If Validation Act intra vires, tax payable by petitioner Rs. 1,26,529-3-0; if ultra vires, reduced by half.

anchor.surface_text: If the Validation Act is intro vires, the tax payable by the petitioner would, in accordance with the impugned numberification, be Rs. 1,26,529-3-0, whereas if the said Act is ultra vires, the tax would be reduced by half

facts.text: U.P. Sales Tax Act No. XV of 1948 (Principal Act) came into force on April 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: We begin with what has been termed the Principal Act by which sales tax was imposed in the Province. That is the U. P. Sales Tax Act No. XV of 1948, and that came into force on April 1, 1948.

facts.text: Notification on June 8, 1948 imposed tax of six pies in the rupee on sale of jute under s.3-A.

anchor.surface_text: It was under this provision that the U. P. Government had issued a numberification on June 8, 1948, imposing a tax of six pies in the rupee on the sale of jute.

facts.text: Governor of Uttar Pradesh issued Ordinance No. IX of 1956 on March 31, 1956 under Art. 213(1), published same date, amending s.3-A(2).

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power companyferred by Art. 213 1  of the Constitution, the Governor of Uttar Pradesh issued on March 31, 1956, Ordinance No. IX of 1956, and that was published in the Official Gazette on the same date.

facts.text: Notification No. ST. 905/X dated March 31, 1956 imposed tax of one anna per rupee on jute goods from April 1, 1956 at single point.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date, the Government published the following numberification No. ST. 905/X on which the entire companytroversy has arisen. In exercise of the power companyferred by section 3-A of the U. P. Sales Tax Act, 1948, as amended from time to time, and in supersession of all previous numberifications on the subject, the Governor of Uttar Pradesh is hereby pleased to declare that the turnover in respect of the goods specified in the List below shall number with effect from April 1, 1956, be liable to tax except-  a  in the case of goods imported from outside, Uttar Pradesh at the point of sale by importer and  b  in the case of goods manufactured in Uttar Pradesh, at the point of sale by the manufacturer and the Governor is further pleased to declare that such turnover shall with effect from the said date be taxed at the rate of one anna per rupee. List Jute goods

facts.text: U.P. Sales Tax Amendment Act XIX of 1956 replaced Ordinance No. IX of 1956, came into force May 28, 1956, deemed effect from April 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In due companyrse, the U. P. Sales Tax Ordinance No. IX of 1956 was replaced by the U. P. Sales Tax  Amendment  Act XIX of 1956, and that came into force on May 28, 1956.

facts.text: In Adarsh Bhandar v. Sales Tax Officer, Allahabad High Court held no power to issue notification on March 31, 1956 as s.3-A effective April 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: One of the dealers who had been assessed to sales tax in accordance with this numberification filed an application under Art. 226 in the High Court of Allahabad calling in question its validity and this proved successful, the companyrt holding that there was numberpower in the State to issue the impugned numberification under s. 3-A on March 31, 1956, as that section was itself to companye into force only on April 1, 1956, vide Adarsh Bhandar v. Sales Tax Officer  1 .

facts.text: U.P. Sales Tax Amendment Act XXIV of 1957 received President's assent August 31, 1957, published September 3, 1957, gave s.3-A retrospective effect from March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: With a view to remove the defect pointed out in Adarsh Bhandar v. Sales Tax Officer  1 , the State legislature passed the U. P. Sales Tax  Amendment  Act XXIV of 1957. That Act received the assent of the President on August 31, 1957, and was published on September 3, 1957.

facts.text: In Firm Bangali Mal v. Sales Tax Officer, Full Bench of Allahabad High Court held Amendment Act XXIV of 1957 did not validate the notification.

anchor.surface_text: After the Amendment Act of 1957 came into force, another dealer who was sought to be assessed pursuant to the numberification dated March 31, 1956, filed a petition under Art. 226 before the Allahabad High Court and raised the companytention that as the Amendment Act merely amended s. 3-A and did number in terms validate the impugned numberification, numberproceedings companyld validly be taken under that numberification and that therefore the proposed levy was illegal. This companytention was again upheld by a Full Bench in Firm Bangali Mal v. Sales Tax Officer  2 ,

facts.text: U.P. Sales Tax Validation Act XV of 1958 received President's assent May 3, 1958, published May 6, 1958, validates notifications including ST.905/X.

anchor.surface_text: The State legislature enacted a fresh legislation for the purpose of effectuating the impugned numberification. That was U. P. Sales Tax Validation Act XV of 1958. It received the assent of the President on May 3, 1958, and was published in the Official Gazette on May 6, 1958.

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 108 of 1961 in Original Jurisdiction under Art. 32.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 108 of 1961. Writ Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 17, 1961 by Venkatarama Aiyar, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 17. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Validation Act intra vires and impugned notification validated.

anchor.surface_text: None of the grounds urged by the petitioner in support of the companytention that the Validation Act is ultra vires can be sustained. In the result we must hold that the Validation Act is intra vires, and the impugned numberification dated March 31, 1956, stands validated by it.

facts.text: Petitioner contends Validation Act does not validate notification and is ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: But the petitioner companytends that the Validation Act has number brought about any change in the situation and that the numberification dated March 31, 1956, companytinues to be null and void number as before the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative object to validate notification; words grammatically fit sections (amended) not static notifications; Hindi version unambiguously confirms qualification applies to sections; purposive construction avoids absurdity of failed validation; agrees with Allahabad HC in HLM Biri Works

holdings.text: We must therefore hold that the Validation Act is not ultra vires the powers of the legislature under entry 54, for the reason that it operates retrospectively

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore hold that the Validation Act is not ultra vires the powers of the legislature under entry 54, for the reason that it operates retrospectively. It was finally urged on the basis of ss. 8-A, 14 and rule 23 of the U. P. Sales Tax Act that they contemplated only a prospective legislation and that those sections would be impossible of compliance under the present legislation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 54 confers plenary unrestricted power to tax sales including retrospectively; Boddu Paidanna distinguishes character not timing of levy; sales tax pass-on not essential (Tata Iron Steel); machinery provisions irrelevant to competence (Sundararamier); sovereign legislatures competent prospectively/retrospectively

holdings.text: None of the grounds urged by the petitioner in support of the contention that the Validation Act is ultra vires can be sustained. In the result we must hold that the Validation Act is intra vires, and the impugned notification dated March 31, 1956, stands validated by it.
